case_name: Shri Kishun, Ram Bali, Jai Shri and Jattan v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 273 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 273 of 1968. Appeal

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 15, 1967 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 478 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 15, 1967 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 478 of 1965. B.

facts.text: Shri Kishun, Ram Bali, Jai Shri and Jattan convicted by Sessions Judge Ballia under section 302 read with section 34 IPC for causing death of Seru aged 45.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Kishun, Ram Bali, Jai Shri and Jattan were convicted by learned Sessions Judge Ballia under section 302 read with section 34 Indian Penal

facts.text: Accused convicted under section 323 read with section 34 IPC for causing injuries to Sadaphal PW 2.

anchor.surface_text: Code for causing the death of Seru  aged 45  and under section 323 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code for causing injuries to Sadaphal  PW

facts.text: Sentenced to imprisonment for life under 302/34 and rigorous imprisonment for one year under 323/34, to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: 2 , and were sentenced to undergo imprisonment for life on the former count and rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year on the latter count.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court affirmed the order of the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The sentences in the case of each accused were ordered to run concurrently. On appeal the High Court of Allahabad affirmed the order of the

facts.text: Ram Bali and Jattan are brothers; Shri Kishun and Jai Shri are brothers and nephews of Ram Bali and Jattan.

anchor.surface_text: The four accused thereafter came to this Court by special leave. ... Ram Bali and Jattan accused are brothers. Likewise, Shri Kishun and Jai Shri

facts.text: Incident occurred on February 13, 1964 about half an hour before sunset.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that on February 13, 1964 about half an hour before sunset Bhagwati  PW 3 , who is aged about 11, and his sisters son

facts.text: Bhagwati PW 3 aged about 11 and Kolahal were playing guchhi in Khalihan of Shri Kishun.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwati  PW 3 , who is aged about 11, and his sisters son Kolahal were playing guchhi  a game played with paisa  in the Khalihan of Shri Kishun

facts.text: Nandlal, son of Shri Kishun, protested playing in his Khalihan, threw away paisa, scuffle with Bhagwati.

anchor.surface_text: accused. Nandlal, son of Shri Kishun, came there and protested against the playing, of the game of guchhi in his Khalihan, Nandlal also threw away

facts.text: Seru aged 45 and Sadaphal PW2 intervened and stopped the scuffle.

anchor.surface_text: in a neighboring field the paisa with which the game was being played. A scuffle then took place between Nandlal and Bhagwati. Seru deceased and

facts.text: Nandlal wept and went to his house.

anchor.surface_text: Nandlal then began to weep and went to his house.

facts.text: Four accused armed with lathis accosted Seru, Sadaphal, Bhagwati and Kolahal in front of Suraj Mal's house.

anchor.surface_text: When they reached in front of the house of one Suraj Mal, the four accused, who were armed with lathies, accosted them.

facts.text: Accused protested beating of Nandlal and belaboured Seru and Sadaphal with lathis.

anchor.surface_text: The accused protested against the beating given to Shri Kishuns son  Nandlal  and at the same time, belaboured Seru and Sadaphal.

facts.text: Seru fell down unconscious after receiving injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Seru on receipt of injuries fell down on the ground and became unconscious.

facts.text: Sada Shiva PW 4 and Bajaram PW 5 arrived on alarm, accused ran away.

anchor.surface_text: On alarm being raised, Sada Shiva  PW 4  and Bajaram  PW 5  reached there, whereupon the accused run away.

facts.text: Sadaphal carried Seru to police station Deoria, then by riksha to PS Beoria, FIR lodged by Sadaphal at 7.05 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: Sadaphal PW carried Seru on a cot to police station Deoria. On the way Seru was put in a riksha. The party then went to police station Beoria

facts.text: Seru died on the way to hospital.

anchor.surface_text: Seru, however, died on the way.

facts.text: Post mortem on Seru by Dr. C. D. Agarwal on February 14, 1964; five injuries found, death due to shock and haemorrhage from head injury.

anchor.surface_text: Post mortem examination on the dead body of Seru was performed by Dr. C. D. Agarwal on February 14, 1964. The following five injuries were found

facts.text: Sadaphal had seven simple injuries caused by blunt weapon like lathi, examined by Dr. Nagrath.

anchor.surface_text: Sadaphal PW on examination by Dr. Nagrath was found to have seven simple injuries caused with blunt weapon like lathi.

facts.text: Defence plea: She buffalo of Seru trespassed into field of Shri Kishun; Jattan caught it; Seru and Sadaphal snatched and assaulted Jattan with lathis.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial the plea of the appellants was that a she buffalo belonging to Seru had trespassed into the field of Shri Kishun accused. Jattan

facts.text: Jai Shri reached on alarm by Jattan and both used lathis in self-defence.

anchor.surface_text: accused caught hold of the she buffalo and was taking it to the cattle pond when Seru and Sadaphal made an effort to snatch The she buffalo.

facts.text: Jattan examined on February 18, 1964, found to have two injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Evidence was led in defence to show that Jattan accused on being examined on February 18, 1964 was found to have two injuries on his person.

facts.text: High Court relied on evidence of four eye-witnesses: Sadaphal PW2, Bhagwati PW3, Sada Shiva PW4, Rajaram PW5.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in maintaining the conviction of the accused appellants relied upon the evidence of four eye witnesses, Sadaphal  PW 2 , Bhagwati

facts.text: No previous enmity between accused and Seru or Sadaphal.

anchor.surface_text: Although the High Court took note of the fact that there did not exist any previous enmity between the accused on the one hand and Seru

facts.text: Supreme Court altered conviction to section 325 read with section 34 IPC, sentenced to 5 years RI, concurrent with 1 year under 323/34.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court Mr. Datar on behalf of the accused-appellants has argued that the case against the accused falls under section 325 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code and number under section 302 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code. issues.text: what was the common intention of the accused in furtherance, of which they caused injuries to Seru and Sadaphal

anchor.surface_text: The liability can only be vicarious under section 34 of the Indian Penal Code and, as such, we have to find out as to what was the common intention of the accused in furtherance, of which they caused injuries to Seru and Sadaphal.

arguments.claim: Liability vicarious under section 34 requiring determination of common intention which was to give severe beating causing grievous hurt

anchor.surface_text: The liability can only be vicarious under section 34 of the Indian Penal Code and, as such, we have to find out as to what was the common intention of the accused in furtherance, of which they caused injuries to Seru and Sadaphal.

arguments.claim: Common intention was to cause grievous injury; one exceeded bounds but others liable only for intended grievous hurt under 325/34

anchor.surface_text: The above finding as well as the broad circumstances of the case go to show that the common intention of the accused was to cause grievous injury to the victim. The fact that one of them exceeded the bound and gave a fatal blow on the head of the deceased would make him personally liable for the fatal injury,

arguments.claim: Since not possible to identify who gave fatal blow, all four accused guilty only under 325/34

anchor.surface_text: As it is not possible on the material on record to find out as to which one of the accused gave the fatal blow, there is no escape from the conclusion that each one of the four accused can only be guilty of the offence under section 325 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the submission made by Mr. Datar is well-founded.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the submission made by Mr. Datar is well-founded. There was no previous enmity between the accused-appellants on the one hand and Seru deceased and Sadaphal PW on  he other.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No previous enmity, sudden occurrence from trifling incident between children, nature of injuries mostly simple except one fatal, no identification of who gave fatal blow.

holdings.text: the common intention of the accused was to cause grievous injury to the victim

anchor.surface_text: The above finding as well as the broad circumstances of the case go to show that the common intention of the accused was to cause grievous injury to the victim. The fact that one of them exceeded the bound and gave a fatal blow on the head of the deceased would make him personally liable for the fatal injury,

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding that common intention was to give severe beating; supported by lack of enmity, sudden nature of incident, and circumstances including injury profile.

holdings.text: The fact that one of them exceeded the bound and gave a fatal blow on the head of the deceased would make him personally liable for the fatal injury, but so far as the other three are concerned, they can be held liable only for the injuries which were caused in furtherance of the common intention and not for the fatal injury.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that one of them exceeded the bound and gave a fatal blow on the head of the deceased would make him personally liable for the fatal injury, but so far as the other three are concerned, they can be held liable only for the injuries which were caused in furtherance of the common intention and not for the fatal injury.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under section 34 IPC, liability is limited to acts done in furtherance of common intention; exceeding bounds leads to personal liability for excess.

holdings.text: As it is not possible on the material on record to find out as to which one of the accused gave the fatal blow, there is no escape from the conclusion that each one of the four accused can only be guilty of the offence under section 325 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: As it is not possible on the material on record to find out as to which one of the accused gave the fatal blow, there is no escape from the conclusion that each one of the four accused can only be guilty of the offence under section 325 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution evidence fails to specify perpetrator of fatal injury; thus all liable vicariously only for common intention of grievous hurt under s.325/34.

holdings.text: We accordingly alter the conviction of each of the accused-appellants from under section 302 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code to that under s. 325 read with s. 34 Indian Penal Code. Each of them is sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of five years on that count.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly alter the conviction of each of the accused-appellants from under section 302 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code to that under s. 325 read with s. 34 Indian Penal Code. Each of them is sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of five years on that count.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on determination of common intention for grievous hurt and inability to attribute fatal injury specifically.

holdings.text: The sentence of rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year awarded to each of the accused under section 323 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code would run concurrently with the above sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The sentence of rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year awarded to each of the accused under section 323 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code would run concurrently with the above sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation of lower court sentencing direction for concurrency.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly alter the companyviction of each of the accused-appellants from under section 302 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code to that under s. 325 read with s. 34 Indian Penal Code. Each of them is sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of five years on that companynt. The sentence of rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year awarded to each of the accused under section 323 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code would run companycurrently with the above sentence.

outcome.relief_summary: Conviction of each accused altered from s.302 r/w s.34 IPC to s.325 r/w s.34 IPC; sentenced to 5 years rigorous imprisonment; sentence under s.323 r/w s.34 IPC directed to run concurrently
directions: Each of the accused-appellants is sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of five years under s.325 r/w s.34 IPC

The holding determines joint liability of all four accused despite inability to identify the one who gave the fatal blow, addressing the issue of whether the offence was murder (requiring assessment of intent and liability) or a lesser offence.

anchor.surface_text: As it is not possible on the material on record to find out as to which one of the accused gave the fatal blow, there is no escape from the conclusion that each one of the four accused can only be guilty of the offence under section 325 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code.

We accordingly alter the companyviction of each of the accused-appellants from under section 302 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code to that under s. 325 read with s. 34 Indian Penal Code. Each of them is sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of five years on that companynt. The sentence of rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year awarded to each of the accused under section 323 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code would run companycurrently with the above sentence.
